verses.text: He who shows mercy by lending to his neighbor keeps the commandments, and supports him with his hand.
verses.comment: The practice of lending to those in need is deeply rooted in the law of Moses and seen as an act of mercy—see also Ex. 22:25. This anticipates the Christian ethic of generosity evidenced in Christ’s teachings (cf. Matt. 5:42, Luke 6:34-35).

verses.text: Lend to your neighbor in his time of need, and pay your debt to your neighbor in due time.
verses.comment: This verse underscores both generosity and personal responsibility. The call to pay back debts echoes biblical justice and faithfulness.

verses.text: Keep your promise and be trustworthy, and you will always find what you need.
verses.comment: Faithfulness in small matters is tied to trust in God for providence. Compare Luke 16:10 for Jesus’ teaching on faithfulness.

verses.text: Many consider a loan to be a gain, and cause trouble to those who helped them.
verses.comment: Here Sirach describes the sorrowful reality of some borrowers, echoing Prov. 22:7 about the borrower being a servant to the lender.

verses.text: He kisses his hands, and speaks humbly, but when payment is due, he delays and blames the times.
verses.comment: Symbolic language expressing false humility. The challenge of encountering unreliable borrowers transcends time and place.

verses.text: If he can repay, he will barely pay half, and will count it as a gain; if not, he will take advantage and rob you of your money.
verses.comment: Sirach realistically warns against imprudence in lending. This teaches discernment within mercy—a wisdom valued by the Church Fathers.

verses.text: Many refuse to lend, not out of stinginess, but from the fear of being cheated needlessly.
verses.comment: Lending unwisely can bring harm to relationships, reminding readers of the human tendency towards ingratitude and injustice.

verses.text: Many refuse to lend, not because they are wicked, but because they have been wronged for no reason.
verses.comment: The wisdom here does not condemn prudent boundaries. Justice and charity must go together.

verses.text: Yet be patient with the humble, and do not make them wait for your help.
verses.comment: Despite caution, generosity is always encouraged toward the poor and needy—an Old Testament theme fulfilled in Christian charity.

verses.text: For the sake of the commandments, help the poor, and do not turn him away in his need.
verses.comment: This reflects God’s command to care for the poor (Deut. 15:7-8), anticipating Christ’s words in Matthew 25:35-40 about serving ‘the least of these’.

verses.text: Lose your silver for a brother or friend, and do not let it rust under a rock to no use.
verses.comment: Jesus echoes this, urging us not to store up treasures on earth but invest in heavenly treasure by good works (cf. Matt. 6:19-20).

verses.text: Lay up your treasure according to the commandments of the Most High, and it will profit you more than gold.
verses.comment: True spiritual treasure is found in obeying God. See also Matt. 6:20 and Ps. 112:9 for the reward promised for generous giving.

verses.text: Store up almsgiving in your treasury, and it will rescue you from every trouble.
verses.comment: Almsgiving, respected as a means for atonement and help in the day of need, echoes throughout the Old and New Testaments (Tob. 4:10, Luke 12:33)—suggesting a link between mercy and salvation.

verses.text: It will fight for you against your enemy better than a strong shield or heavy spear.
verses.comment: Just as God is pictured as our shield and defender, so generosity acts as our protector against adversity—reminding believers to trust in divine rather than material security.

verses.text: A good man will be surety for his neighbor, but one who has lost all shame will abandon him.
verses.comment: The concept of ‘surety’ or guaranteeing another’s debt was well-known (cf. Prov. 11:15). Moral character is founded on sacrificial love, prefiguring Christ’s redemptive sacrifice for all. See John 15:13.

verses.text: Do not forget the kindness of your guarantor, for he has put up his life for you.
verses.comment: The parallel to Christ’s laying down his life for friends (John 15:13) is vivid here, teaching gratitude and the remembrance of sacrificial love.

verses.text: A sinner neglects the kindness of his guarantor, and the ingrate abandons his rescuer.
verses.comment: Ingratitude is listed among serious faults here—reflect how the New Testament emphasizes thankfulness (cf. Col. 3:15)—especially toward Christ, our redeemer.

verses.text: Surety has ruined many who were prosperous, and has shaken them like the waves of the sea; it has driven powerful men from home, and forced them to wander among foreign nations.
verses.comment: A stark warning about financial indiscretion. The consequences of imprudence in money matters were just as serious then as today.

verses.text: The sinner who is eager for profit brings trouble upon himself, and neglects his own gain for the sake of others.
verses.comment: Selfish gain is condemned, and the contrast is drawn with those who act justly and prudently.

verses.text: Help your neighbor according to your means, but take care that you do not fall yourself.
verses.comment: True charity must be free, not coerced or manipulative, teaching the need for right intention in good deeds (cf. Matt. 6:1).

verses.text: The essentials of life are water, bread, clothing, and a house to assure your privacy.
verses.comment: This repetition for emphasis highlights the deep moral and relational obligation linked to such acts; see again John 15:13.

verses.text: A poor person living under his own humble roof is better off than feasting lavishly in the house of another.
verses.comment: Negligent behavior is not only a personal fault but endangers the wider community—the idea of mutual responsibility is at the heart of God’s law.

verses.text: Be content whether you have little or much, for then you will not be reproached as a guest.
verses.comment: Wisdom literature encourages careful discernment in lending and relationships—teaching balance between trust and prudence.

verses.text: It is a wretched life to go from house to house; as a guest, you ought not open your mouth.
verses.comment: Hospitality is a recurring biblical theme (cf. Heb. 13:2). The spiritual life involves not only faith, but also right relationships and gratitude to those who receive us.

verses.text: You will act as host and provide drink but will not be thanked, and you will hear harsh words such as these:
verses.comment: Christian humility and hospitality are intertwined here—echoed in the life and teaching of Jesus (cf. Luke 14:10, John 13:14).

verses.text: "Come here, stranger, set the table; let me eat what you have brought."
verses.comment: Abraham’s hospitality to strangers (Genesis 18) is a model. Generosity toward guests has spiritual rewards (cf. Matt. 10:42).

verses.text: "Go away, stranger, for a more distinguished guest has arrived; my brother has come, and I need the guest room."
verses.comment: This covers the consequences of ingratitude and disrespect. The biblical virtue of thanksgiving is deeply tied to the spiritual life.

verses.text: It is hard for a discerning person to endure insults about lodging and the reproaches of a lender.
verses.comment: Foolishness and ungratefulness corrupt the blessing of hospitality, highlighting a larger spiritual lesson: to approach both spiritual and temporal gifts with gratitude and reverence.
